conclusion: Analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves backward.
A black cup/container with shadow A.
A green avocado or similar spherical object with shadow B.
An object casting shadow C (partially visible in image).
A waffle or similar textured square item with shadow D.
When a light source moves relative to an object, the size and position of the shadow changes.
When a light source moves backward, the light rays become more parallel, causing shadows to become closer in size to the actual objects.
Shadows will generally become smaller and more defined when the light source moves backward.
When a light source moves backward while remaining above the objects, shadows will move closer to being directly beneath their respective objects.
The 'offset' of each shadow from its object will decrease when the light source moves backward.
Shadow A will move closer to being directly under the cup and will become smaller.
Shadow B will move closer to being directly under the avocado and will become smaller.
Shadow C will move closer to the object creating it, becoming less offset.
Shadow D will move closer to being directly under the waffle and will become smaller with more defined edges.
All shadows will become smaller as the light rays become more parallel.
All shadows will move closer to being directly underneath their respective objects.
The shadows will have more defined edges and will more closely match the actual shape of the objects.
The overall 'spread' of shadows across the surface will decrease as they concentrate more directly beneath the objects.
